Question: In the harbour of which city was the Greenpeace flagship Rainbow Warrior sunk in 1985?  Auckland, Wellington, Dunedin, or Christchurch?
Comments: The sinking of Rainbow Warrior, codenamed Opération Satanique, was a state terrorism bombing operation by the "action" branch of the French foreign intelligence agency, the Directorate-General for External Security, carried out on 10 July 1985 - Wikipedia

Question: True or False, Napoleon Bonaparte was defeated in the Battle of Waterloo.
Comments: The Battle of Waterloo, which took place in Belgium on June 18, 1815, marked the final defeat of Napoleon Bonaparte, who conquered much of Europe in the early 19th century. - HISTORY

Question: Complete this sentence: The __________ ____________ was a document declared by Abraham Lincoln to abolish slavery in the United States.
Comments: On September 22, 1862, President Abraham Lincoln issued the preliminary Emancipation Proclamation, which declared that as of January 1, 1863, all enslaved people in the states currently engaged in rebellion against the Union “shall be then, thenceforward, and forever free.” - HISTORY

Question: What year was the Treaty of Versailles signed?
Comments: The Treaty of Versailles, signed in 1919 at the Palace of Versailles in Paris at the end of World War I, codified peace terms between Germany and the victorious Allies. - HISTORY

Question: What is the smallest country in the world by landmass and population?
Comments: With an area of 49 hectares (121 acres) and a 2019 population of about 453, it is the smallest state in the world both by area and population. - Wikipedia

Question: True or False, the current FEDERAL capital of Brazil is Rio de Janeiro.
Comments: Rio de Janeiro became the colonial capital in 1763 and was the capital of independent Brazil from 1822 until 1960, when the national capital was moved to the new city of Brasília - Britannica

Question: Which country is also called The Netherlands? Norway, Holland, Belgium, or Luxembourg?
Comments: The Netherlands, informally known as Holland, is a country located in northwestern Europe with overseas territories in the Caribbean.

Question: Complete this sentence: "The world's largest desert is in ________"
Comments: Antarctica is, on average, the coldest, driest, and windiest of the continents, and it has the highest average elevation. It is mainly a polar desert, with annual precipitation of over 200 mm (8 in) along the coast and far less inland. - Wikipedia

Question: In The Matrix, does Neo take the blue pill or the red pill?
Comments: The red pill and blue pill represent a choice between the willingness to learn a potentially unsettling or life-changing truth by taking the red pill or remaining in the contented experience of ordinary reality with the blue pill. - Wikipedia

Question: What year was the first Avatar movie released in the US?
Comments: Avatar was released on December 18, 2009, and is the highest grossing film of all-time. The second installment, The Way of Water, was released on December 16, 2022. - Wikipedia

Question: In the movie Forrest Gump, which country did Forrest Gump travel to as part of the All-American Ping-Pong Team for diplomatic reasons? Vietnam, Sweden, China, France?
Comments: After suffering injuries in Vietnam, Forrest develops an aptitude for Table tennis and joins the U.S. Army team—eventually competing against Chinese teams on a goodwill tour. - Wikipedia

Question: True or False, the 2001 movie Shrek was the first ever film to be made in full CGI.
Comments: Created in 1995, Toy Story was the first entirely computer-animated feature film, as well as the first feature film from Pixar. - Wikipedia

Question: Which planet is closest to the Sun? Mars, Saturn, Venus, or Mercury?
Comments: Mercury is the first planet from the Sun and the smallest planet in the Solar System. - Wikipedia

Question: True or False, hot water freezes faster than cold water.
Comments: The Mpemba effect is the name given to the observation that a liquid (typically water) which is initially hot can freeze faster than the same liquid which begins cold, under otherwise similar conditions. - Wikipedia

Question: What “P” term refers to a virus, bacteria, or other agent that causes disease?
Comments: In biology, a pathogen, in the oldest and broadest sense, is any organism or agent that can produce disease. A pathogen may also be referred to as an infectious agent, or simply a germ. - Wikipedia

Question: Complete this sentence: "There are 118 elements in the _______ _____ of elements"
Comments: The periodic table, also known as the periodic table of the elements, arranges the chemical elements into rows ("periods") and columns ("groups"). It is an organizing icon of chemistry and is widely used in physics and other sciences. - Wikipedia

Question: The Olympic games are held every how many years?
Comments: The Olympic Games are normally held every four years, and since 1994, have alternated between the Summer and Winter Olympics every two years during the four-year period. - Wikipedia

Question: What country does the famous soccer player Cristiano Ronaldo come from?
Comments: Widely regarded as one of the greatest players of all time, Ronaldo has won five Ballon d'Or awards and four European Golden Shoes, the most by a European player. He has won 32 trophies in his career, including seven league titles, five UEFA Champions Leagues, the UEFA European Championship and the UEFA Nations League. - Wikipedia

Question: True or False, New Zealand won the first ever Rugby World Cup.
Comments: The 1987 Rugby World Cup was the first Rugby World Cup. It was co-hosted by New Zealand and Australia. The tournament was won by New Zealand, who were the strong favourites and won all their matches comfortably. - Wikipedia

Question: Complete this sentence: The term ______ is used when a player knocks down all pins on the first ball roll in bowling.
Comments: In bowling, a strike means that all of the pins have been knocked down on the first ball roll of a frame. On a bowling scoresheet, a strike is marked by an "X". - Wikipedia

Question: What is the title of the most commercially successful video game of all time?
Comments: The best-selling video game to date is Minecraft, a sandbox game released by Mojang in May 2009 for a wide range of PC, mobile and console platforms, selling more than 238 million copies across all platforms. - Wikipedia

Question: True or False, Pong holds the distinction of being the very first video game ever created.
Comments: Tennis for Two (also known as Computer Tennis) is a sports video game that simulates a game of tennis, and was one of the first games developed in the early history of video games. - Wikipedia

Question: How many mainline Resident Evil games exist?
Comments: There are 10 core Resident Evil games: RE 0-7, Village, and Code: Veronica. However, the total number of Resident Evil console games — including spinoffs and remakes — sits around 30. That number rises near 60 when accounting for mobile and pachinko games. - IGN

Question: Complete this sentence: "______ is a leading video game company known for creating video game distribution platform Steam."
Comments: Valve Corporation, also known as Valve Software, is an American video game developer, publisher, and digital distribution company headquartered in Bellevue, Washington. It is the developer of the software distribution platform Steam and the franchises Half-Life, Counter-Strike, Portal, Day of Defeat, Team Fortress, Left 4 Dead, and Dota. - Wikipedia

Question: True or False, the house charity for Kupe is the Himalayan Trust.
Comments: The Kupe house charity is Kiwis for Kiwi an organization dedicated to rescuing kiwis all over the world. Kiwis for Kiwi is a conservation-based, not for-profit organisation. - Our Endangered World

Question: Complete this sentence: The ______ _______ is the official mascot for Snell house.
Comments: The black panther is known for its speed and agility. Its formidable predatory instincts incite fear and nervousness into any potential opposition. Its strength, courage and intellect are further qualities that enhance its presence in the jungle. - Macleans College

Question: What year was Macleans College first opened?
Comments: Macleans College was opened in 1980 by the Governor General, Sir David Beattie, with a roll of 199 students. - Macleans College

Question: Which house in Macleans is the only two-storey house? Upham, Te Kanawa, Batten, Rutherford?
Comments: Batten house, named after Jean Gardner Batten, is the only house in Macleans to have two-storeys.

Question: Which famous Pokémon has electricity-storing pouches on its cheeks and is also Ash Ketchum's personal companion?
Comments: Pikachu is a short, chubby rodent Pokémon. It is covered in yellow fur with two horizontal brown stripes on its back. It has a small mouth, long, pointed ears with black tips, and brown eyes. Each cheek is a red circle that contains a pouch for electricity storage. - Bulbapedia

Question: True or False, ghouls can consume grape soda without getting sick in 'Tokyo Ghoul'.
Comments: Besides water and coffee, a ghoul can only feed on humans and other ghouls. They are unable to digest any other type of food due to a particular enzyme their bodies produce. - OSG

Question: Complete this sentence: _______ was the first member of the First Levi Squad to die in 'Attack on Titan'?
Comments: Günther is a soldier who has logged 47 Titan kills, 7 solo. On the 57th expedition to the lands outside the wall, he is ambushed and killed during the retreat in the forest by Annie in her human form (using the vertical maneuvering equipment stolen from Marco). - Wikipedia

Question: How many Dragon Balls are there in DBZ?
Comments: Dragon Balls are the namesake artifact of the Dragon Ball series. They are orange, crystalline spheres with the ability to call forth the Eternal Dragon Shenron which has the ability to grant wishes to anyone who gathers all seven of them. - Dragon Ball Updates Wiki
